notes.DDR4: Speed bin codes follow JEDEC JESD79-4 standard. PC4 prefix indicates DDR4, followed by data rate and speed bin letter(s).
notes.DDR5: Speed grades follow JEDEC JESD400-5C standard. PC5 prefix indicates DDR5, followed by data rate number.

DDR4.description: DDR4 density codes (Byte 4, bits 3-0) per JEDEC JESD79-4

DDR5.description: DDR5 density codes (Byte 4, bits 3-0) per JEDEC JESD400-5C

DDR4.description: Device width codes (Byte 5, bits 2-0) per JEDEC JESD79-4
DDR4.notes: x4 is common for server modules (RDIMM/LRDIMM), x8 for desktop (UDIMM)

DDR5.description: Device width codes (Byte 6, bits 2-0) per JEDEC JESD400-5C

DDR4.description: Module type codes (Byte 3, bits 3-0) per JEDEC JESD79-4

DDR5.description: Module type codes (Byte 3, bits 3-0) per JEDEC JESD400-5C

manufacturerIds.description: JEDEC Manufacturer ID codes (Byte 117-118 for DDR4, Byte 512-513 for DDR5)
manufacturerIds.note: Manufacturer IDs are assigned by JEDEC. First byte is continuation, second byte is manufacturer code.

prefix.detailed: M prefix indicates this is a complete memory module part number, not a DRAM component part number

series.detailed: Series number identifies the product family. 3xx series = DDR4 modules, 4xx series = DDR5 modules

config.detailed: Two-letter code or letter+digit indicating module capacity, organization (ranks, data width), and form factor

heuristics.firstLetter: A = Standard capacity range, B = Higher capacity, etc.
heuristics.secondChar: Letter or digit indicating specific capacity/organization combination
heuristics.pattern: First letter often indicates capacity tier, second indicates organization variant

speed.detailed: Numeric code indicating target data rate. Note: This is approximate and may vary. Real speed must be verified from SPD data.
speed.warning: Speed code 40 can mean either 3200 MHz (PC4-3200AA) or 2933 MHz (PC4-2933Y) depending on model. Always verify from SPD.

formFactor.detailed: Single letter code indicating module type and power characteristics

codes.B: LRDIMM (Load-Reduced DIMM) - Server module with data buffer
codes.C: RDIMM (Registered DIMM) - Server module with register
codes.M: RDIMM (Registered DIMM) - Server module with register (alternative code)

revision.detailed: Module revision identifier, may include package type and other variant information

suffix.detailed: Three-letter suffix code with specific meaning

examples.CWE: Revision C, Commercial temp (0-95°C), Halogen Free
examples.CVF: Revision C, Commercial temp, different finish

40_alt.note: Alternative: 40 can also mean 2933 MHz in some models (e.g., M393A8G40MB2)

speedCodeMapping.formulaNote: Formula speedNum * 80 provides approximate MHz. Actual speed depends on model, series, and binning.
speedCodeMapping.warning: Speed code mapping is approximate. Real speed should be verified from SPD data. Code 40 can mean either 3200 or 2933 MHz depending on model.

heuristics.seriesDependency: Speed code meaning may depend on series (e.g., M393 series with code 40 often means 2933 MHz)
heuristics.formFactorDependency: Server modules (RDIMM/LRDIMM) may have different speed code interpretations than desktop (UDIMM)
heuristics.verification: Always verify actual speed from SPD Byte 18 (tCK MTB) and Byte 125 (tCK FTB) for DDR4
heuristics.capacityInference: Higher capacity modules (64GB+) often use lower speed codes for same actual speed
heuristics.generationPattern: DDR5 modules may use different encoding schemes than DDR4

crossReference.description: Speed code interpretation depends on multiple factors
factors: Form factor (UDIMM vs RDIMM vs LRDIMM)

capacityInference.description: Heuristics for inferring module capacity from part number
capacityInference.note: Capacity inference is approximate. Actual capacity should be verified from SPD data.

organizationInference.description: Heuristics for inferring organization (ranks × data width) from part number

patterns.x4: Common for server modules (RDIMM/LRDIMM), enables higher capacity
patterns.x8: Common for desktop modules (UDIMM), better compatibility
patterns.x16: Less common, used in specific applications

configCodeHeuristics.description: Configuration codes follow patterns but are not fully standardized
configCodeHeuristics.firstLetter: A = Standard capacity tier, B = Higher capacity, C = Very high capacity
configCodeHeuristics.secondChar: Letter or digit indicating specific organization (ranks × data width)
configCodeHeuristics.note: Exact mapping requires manufacturer documentation or SPD data verification

examples.CWE: Revision C, Commercial temp (0-95°C), Halogen Free
examples.CVF: Revision C, Commercial temp, different finish
examples.DWE: Revision D, Commercial temp, Halogen Free

patterns.description: Micron standard format (DRAM component part number)
notes: MT format is for DRAM component part numbers, not module part numbers
Example: MT40A512M16LY = 4Gb DDR4, 512Mb, x16, specific speed grade
Module part numbers use different formats (e.g., 144ASQ16G72LSZ)
MTA format is for complete memory module part numbers
Structure similar to MT but for modules rather than components

busWidth.description: Module bus width (72 = 72-bit with ECC: 64 data + 8 ECC)

features.description: Feature codes (LSZ = Low Halogen, 1.0mm pitch FBGA)

suffix.description: Optional suffix with speed, power, temperature, revision

breakdown.ASQ: Product Family: Server RDIMM memory (ASQ = Server/Enterprise)
breakdown.72: Bus Width: 72-bit module (64 data + 8 ECC bits)
breakdown.suffixExample: -2S9E1 = 16Gb density, Standard Power, DDR4-2933, Extended temp, Revision 1

notes: 144-pin FBGA is standard for server memory modules
72-bit bus width indicates ECC support (64 data + 8 ECC)
16Gb density is common for high-capacity server modules
Low Halogen (L) indicates RoHS compliance
Extended temperature range (E) suitable for server environments

patterns.description: SK Hynix HMA format (Module part number)

breakdown.codeStructure: Capacity code + Organization + Speed + Die revision + Voltage
breakdown.suffixFormat: Temperature code + Lead finish code (e.g., XN = Commercial temp, Halogen Free)

heuristics.organizationCodes: Middle codes indicate organization (U6 = UDIMM, R7 = RDIMM, G = x8, J = x4)
heuristics.speedCodes: Speed grade codes (R8 = 3200 MHz, R4 = 3200 MHz variant)
heuristics.dieCodes: Die revision codes (D = D-die, J = J-die, C = C-die)

notes: HMA format encodes multiple parameters in compact form
Decoding requires understanding of SK Hynix internal coding scheme
Suffix typically indicates temperature grade and lead finish

patterns.description: SK Hynix H5 format (DRAM part number)
patterns.note: DRAM component part number, not module part number

breakdown.speed: Data rate in hundreds of MHz (24 = 2400, 32 = 3200)

notes: ValueRAM is Kingston's value-oriented memory line
Common for desktop and workstation applications
Speed code typically represents data rate in hundreds of MHz
Fury series is Kingston's gaming/high-performance line
Often includes XMP profiles for overclocking
DDR5 Fury modules support XMP 3.0

prefix.description: HP = Kingston HP Series (Server memory for HP servers)

d4_2.description: D = Data Width or Type indicator

breakdown.HP: Kingston HP Series - Server memory for HP servers

notes: HP series is specifically designed for HP ProLiant and similar servers
64GB capacity suggests high-density chips (32Gb or 16Gb per chip)
x4 organization is typical for server memory architecture
2 Rank configuration is standard for high-capacity server modules

series.description: Series code (K = Vengeance LPX, L = Vengeance RGB, R = Vengeance Pro)

notes: Corsair uses clear, human-readable format
Capacity and speed are explicitly stated in part number
CAS Latency is included for easy identification
Kit size indicates number of modules included

patterns.description: Corsair format with additional suffix (e.g., CMK16GX4M2B3200C16W)
patterns.note: Extended format with additional feature code (W = White, B = Black, etc.)

kitType.description: Kit type (D = Dual channel, S = Single)

capacity.description: Total kit capacity in GB (16 = 16GB kit)

series.description: Series code (G = Gaming, R = Ripjaws, T = Trident)

breakdown.capacity: Total kit capacity (divide by kit size for per-module)

notes: G.Skill format is very explicit about speed and CAS latency
Capacity is total kit capacity, not per-module
Series codes indicate product line and target market
Crucial is a Micron brand
Speed codes may use encoding different from explicit MHz
Format is similar to Micron but with CT prefix

patterns.note: Team Group uses various formats, often with explicit capacity and speed

notes: ADATA XPG is gaming-oriented line
Format includes explicit speed and CAS latency
Variant codes indicate color/design options

Samsung.40: Speed code 40 can mean either 3200 MHz (PC4-3200AA) or 2933 MHz (PC4-2933Y) depending on the model. Always verify from SPD data.
Samsung.43: Speed code 43 = 3200 MHz, not 3440 MHz as formula would suggest.

speedCodeWarnings.general: Speed codes in part numbers are manufacturer-specific and may not follow linear formulas. Always verify actual speed from SPD data when available.

partNumberTypes.module: Module part numbers identify complete memory modules (e.g., M386AAG40BM3, HP32D4R2D4HCI-64)
partNumberTypes.dram: DRAM part numbers identify individual memory chips (e.g., K4A8G085WE, MT40A512M16LY)
partNumberTypes.note: Module part numbers are more useful for SPD programming as they describe the complete module

decodingPrinciples.manufacturerSpecific: Each manufacturer uses different encoding schemes
decodingPrinciples.notStandardized: Part number formats are not fully standardized across manufacturers
decodingPrinciples.verification: Always verify decoded information against actual SPD data when possible
decodingPrinciples.heuristic: Decoding is based on patterns, documentation, and heuristics, not guaranteed accuracy

spdRestoration.description: Part number decoding helps restore SPD when original data is lost
spdRestoration.limitations: Not all SPD parameters can be determined from part number alone
spdRestoration.requiredFields: Critical fields: Module Type, Density, Organization, Speed, Ranks
spdRestoration.optionalFields: Timing parameters, voltage, temperature range may need default values
spdRestoration.verification: Restored SPD should be verified against known good examples when possible

Samsung.formatVariations: Samsung uses multiple formats: M3xx (DDR4), M4xx (DDR5), with config codes that can be letters (AA) or letter+digit (A8)
Samsung.speedCodeAmbiguity: Speed code 40 is ambiguous - can mean 3200 or 2933 MHz depending on series and model
Samsung.seriesMeaning: Series number (3xx/4xx) indicates generation and application (desktop vs server)
Samsung.densityEvolution: Density codes in config: A8 (8GB per chip) → A4 (4GB) → A2 (2GB) → A1 (1GB)
Samsung.reliability: Samsung modules are known for reliability and are widely used in servers

Micron.formatVariations: Micron uses MT (component), MTA (module), and numeric formats (144ASQ...) for server modules
Micron.serverFormat: Server module format (144ASQ...) encodes package, family, density, generation, bus width, features
Micron.suffixEncoding: Suffix encodes density, power, speed, temperature, and revision in compact form
Micron.crucialBrand: Crucial is Micron's consumer brand, uses CT prefix
Micron.enterpriseFocus: Micron has strong presence in enterprise/server memory market

SK Hynix.compactEncoding: HMA format uses very compact encoding with multiple parameters in single code
SK Hynix.decodingComplexity: Full decoding requires detailed SK Hynix documentation due to compact encoding
SK Hynix.dieCodes: Die revision codes indicate process node and die type (D-die, J-die, C-die, M-die)
SK Hynix.serverPresence: Strong presence in server memory market alongside Samsung and Micron

Kingston.multipleSeries: Kingston uses different formats: KVR (ValueRAM), KF (Fury), HP (HP server series)
Kingston.seriesSpecific: Each series has different encoding rules and target markets
Kingston.valueOriented: KVR (ValueRAM) is value-oriented, KF (Fury) is gaming/high-performance
Kingston.oemPartnerships: HP series shows OEM partnerships for server memory

Corsair.gamingFocus: Corsair focuses on gaming and enthusiast market
Corsair.explicitFormat: Part numbers explicitly state capacity, speed, and CAS latency
Corsair.seriesVariety: Multiple series: LPX (low profile), RGB (with lighting), Pro (high-end)
Corsair.xmpSupport: Most Corsair modules include XMP profiles for overclocking

G.Skill.overclocking: G.Skill specializes in high-performance, overclocking-oriented memory
G.Skill.explicitSpecs: Part numbers clearly show speed and CAS latency
G.Skill.seriesDiversity: Multiple series: Ripjaws (value), Trident (high-end), Flare (AMD optimized)
G.Skill.binning: Known for aggressive binning and high-speed modules

Crucial.value: Good balance of performance and price
Crucial.format: Uses CT prefix with encoded speed codes

spdRestorationGuidelines.description: Guidelines for restoring SPD data from part number

moduleType.description: Must be determined from form factor code (B=LRDIMM, C=RDIMM, K=UDIMM)

density.description: Can be inferred from config code or capacity, but may need adjustment
density.verification: Calculate module capacity and verify against expected value

organization.description: Inferred from config code or form factor patterns

speed.description: From speed code, but may be ambiguous (e.g., code 40)
speed.calculation: tCK (ns) = 1000 / speedMHz, then convert to MTB/FTB

partNumber.description: Write decoded part number to SPD

defaultValues.description: Default values when cannot be determined from part number
defaultValues.timings: Use JEDEC standard timings for the speed grade
defaultValues.height: Standard DIMM height (15mm base + height code)

verification.description: Always verify restored SPD against known good examples when possible

speedToBin.description: Quick reference: Speed (MHz) to JEDEC Speed Bin code

formFactorToModuleType.description: Form factor code to SPD Module Type byte value
